channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: ISIS Caliphate Crumbles as Last Village in Syria Falls
item.media:description: A member of the Syrian Democratic Forces shooting at an Islamic State drone last month near Baghuz, Syria.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: American-backed forces took the last remnant of territory under Islamic State rule in Syria, but signs of the group’s resurgence are already visible.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Angry Over Brexit Stalemate, Thousands March in London to Demand Second Vote
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered to march in London on Saturday to call for a “People’s Vote” on Brexit.
item.description: Thousands of protesters in London began marching on Saturday from Hyde Park to Parliament in a last-ditch effort to reverse Britain’s looming split from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER and PALKO KARASZ

item.title: From ‘No Problem’ to No Deal: How Brexit Supporters Embraced the Cliff Edge
item.media:description: Pro-Brexit demonstrators in London. Among many supporters of leaving the European Union, a gradualist goal of achieving a less restrictive relationship has been replaced by the idea of walking away with no deal at all.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Frustration and numbness have driven many Britons to embrace the high-risk solution of simply walking away from negotiations with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: As Thailand Prepares to Vote, the Likely Winner Is Clear. But the Aftermath Isn’t.
item.media:description: “Nothing about this upcoming election is free and fair,” said Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, the leader of Future Forward, a new youth-focused party that has enjoyed a groundswell of online support.
item.description: A populist party looks set to prevail on Sunday. But waiting in the wings, and even on the ballots, is the military.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: North Korea Seeks to Split Alliance Between South Korea and U.S.
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, in the center of this television screen at Seoul Train Station last year, has sought to mediate between North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, right, and President Trump.
item.description: Since the summit meeting between Kim Jong-un and President Trump in Vietnam ended without a deal, North Korea has urged South Korea to distance itself from the United States.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Defying Allies, Italy Signs On to New Silk Road With China
item.media:description: Crowds waiting to welcome President Xi on Friday. Italy became the first of the Group of 7 nations to take part in China’s “One Belt One Road” project.
item.description: The move by Italy to join China’s “One Belt One Road” project crystallized shifting geopolitical balances and the populist Italian government’s willingness to break with its traditional partners.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: After Deadly Insider Attack, U.S. Airstrikes Kill 14 Civilians, Afghans Say
item.media:description: Men standing over the bodies of people they said were killed during a military operation on Saturday in Kunduz Province, Afghanistan.
item.description: American and Afghan forces traded fire, provoked by a Taliban insider. Then, Afghan officials say, an American airstrike hit the home of a large refugee family.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM, ROD NORDLAND and FAHIM ABED
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Death Toll Rises in Iraq Ferry Accident, and Governor’s Resignation Is Sought
item.media:description: A vigil for victims of the sunken ferry in Baghdad on Friday.
item.description: At least 97 people have died in the accident, which turned a festive Kurdish New Year celebration this week into a scene of horror.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Violence Dips in Week 19 of ‘Yellow Vest’ Protests
item.media:description: Protesters gathering in Paris. After months of ritual gatherings every Saturday, their number is a fraction of the more than 250,000 who demonstrated across the country in the movement’s early days.
item.description: The number of protesters has dwindled over the past months. But a surge of violence last weekend had renewed scrutiny of the government’s handling of the demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Pope Replaces Chilean Cardinal Accused of Sexual Abuse Cover-Up
item.media:description: The 77-year-old Cardinal Ezzati had submitted his resignation two years ago when he reached the mandatory retirement age of 75 but but pope Francis kept him on. Cardinal Ezzati became the flash point of survivors’ ire for mishandling several cases of abuse.
item.description: Pope Francis replaced Cardinal Ricardo Ezzati, the embattled archbishop of Santiago, Chile, who was embroiled in a sex abuse and cover-up scandal.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Golan Heights Was Once an Arab Rallying Cry. Not Anymore.
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier looking toward Syria from the Golan Heights, a strategic area that gives whoever controls it a distinct military advantage over the surrounding region.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: The muted Arab response to President Trump’s call to recognize Israeli sovereignty over the territory shows Syria’s weakness amid a reordered Arab world.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: How Strongmen Turned Interpol Into Their Personal Weapon
item.media:description: After the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Interpol expanded and sped up the dissemination of red notices to bolster global law enforcement. Today, that decision opened the door to abuse by authoritarian governments.
item.description: Time and again, people inside and outside Interpol warned that the world’s largest international police organization was leaving itself vulnerable to manipulation.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO

item.title: With a Second President in Jail, Brazil’s Carwash Probe Lives on
item.media:description: Former Brazilian President Michel Temer after being arrested on Thursday in Sao Paulo.
item.description: The detention of former president Michel Temer has triggered breathless coverage, rampant speculation and mocking Tweets.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO and LETÍCIA CASADO

item.title: In Christchurch, New Zealand, One Family Among Many Buries a Son
item.media:description: Family and friends of Atta Elayyan gathered in Christchurch, New Zealand, on Thursday, the day before he and dozens of other victims of the mosque attacks were buried. His 1-year-old daughter, Aya, is fourth from the right.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Atta Elayyan, 33, was one of the many victims of the mosque attacks laid to rest in a mass funeral on Friday. His loved ones told his story.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: More Than 100 Killed Amid Escalating Violence in Mali
item.media:description: Members of the Malian Army patrolling on Saturday in Anderamboukane.
item.description: Gunmen killed dozens of Fulani herders in one of the deadliest such attacks in a region reeling from worsening ethnic and jihadist violence.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Boeing Was ‘Go, Go, Go’ to Beat Airbus With the 737 Max
item.media:description: Work on a 737 Max 8 this week at Boeing’s plant in Renton, Wash. When Airbus competed for a big order from American Airlines in 2011, Boeing opted to update its 737 rather than design a new jet.
item.description: Caught short by its rival’s gains, Boeing raced to update its workhorse jet rather than design a new one. Workers describe a hectic project, but say they hadn’t felt safety was compromised.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GELLES, NATALIE KITROEFF, JACK NICAS and REBECCA R. RUIZ
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

item.title: Gunmen Storm Somalia Government Building, Killing Minister and Others
item.description: Security forces had battled five assailants who entered a building housing two ministries in Mogadishu. The militant group Shabab claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sexual Assault on Flights: Experts Recommend Ways to Stay Safe and Combat It
item.media:description: Sexual assaults on flights have gained heightened attention by law enforcement, airline workers and the industry in the wake of high-profile cases and the #MeToo movement, officials say.
item.description: The issue gained heightened attention in the wake of high-profile cases and the #MeToo movement, officials say.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Bus Fire in China Kills Dozens of People
item.description: The long-distance coach bus was taking tourists to Mao Zedong’s hometown when the fire erupted, according to Chinese state media. At least 26 people were killed.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: New Zealand Bans the Christchurch Suspect’s Manifesto
item.media:description: A memorial for the victims of the shootings at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand. A ruling banning the suspect’s manifesto is part of a wider strategy by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern to undermine his attempts to gain global notoriety.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The alleged gunman’s statement has been classified as “objectionable,” making it illegal to possess or distribute it anywhere in the country.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Mueller Report, North Korea Sanctions, N.C.A.A.: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Death Toll in Africa Climbs Past 600 After Cyclone
item.media:description: Children carrying drinking water on Friday along the border between Mozambique and Zimbabwe.
item.description: With the flooding easing in parts of cyclone-stricken Mozambique on Friday, fears are rising that the waters could yield many more bodies.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies

item.title: Maduro Digs In. It’s an Old Strategy, but It May Work.
item.media:description: The opposition leader Juan Guaidó during a rally on Friday in Anaco, Venezuela.
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and the opposition leader Juan Guaidó have been playing a waiting game as each claims to be the country’s rightful leader. But Mr. Maduro seems to be taking the lead.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Pompeo Denounces Hezbollah in Lebanon, With an Israeli Audience in Mind
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s attack on Hezbollah is expected to give a boost to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and EDWARD WONG

item.title: Truck Driver in Crash That Devastated a Hockey Team Is Sentenced to 8 Years
item.media:description: The driver, Jaskirat Singh Sidhu, leaving court after being sentenced on Friday in Saskatchewan.
item.media:credit: Kayle Neis/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: The driver sped past five signs warning him to stop before colliding with a bus carrying the Humboldt Broncos. Sixteen people died.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: White House Says ISIS’s Last Bastion Fell. So Why Is There Still Fighting?
item.media:description: A Syrian Democratic Forces fighter with weapons seized from the Islamic State. The extremist group’s remnants remain hunkered down in the village of Baghuz.
item.description: Military officials said clashes in Syria against the Islamic State hadn’t stopped, hours after the White House press secretary claimed the caliphate was “100 percent eliminated.”
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Generals Are Back in Israel’s Political Vanguard
item.media:description: From left, the Blue and White political alliance leaders Gabi Ashkenazi, Moshe Yaalon, Benny Gantz, and Yair Lapid this month at the Israel-Gaza border.
item.description: The return of the generals to Israeli politics is viewed as an emergency call-up by those hoping to rout right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Trump Overrules Own Experts on Sanctions, in Favor to North Korea
item.media:description: Kim Il Sung Square in Pyongyang, North Korea. President Trump’s decision created confusion at the highest levels of government.
item.description: “President Trump likes Chairman Kim, and he doesn’t think these sanctions will be necessary,” said Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: What’s Going On Between Canada and China? Our Experts Share Their Thoughts.
item.media:description: Outside an extradition hearing for Meng Wanzhou in Vancouver, British Columbia.
item.description: The Times gathered four correspondents and an editor to discuss the currently fraught relations between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Trilobites: An Elusive Whale Is Found All Around the World
item.description: Researchers are learning about a newly identified species of baleen whales, tracing sightings and sounds to learn that they stay mainly in tropical waters.
item.dc:creator: KAREN WEINTRAUB

item.title: Brexit Deal is Still Unacceptable, Key Government Ally Says
item.media:description: Arlene Foster, the leader of Northern Ireland’s Democratic Unionist Party and the deputy leader, Nigel Dodds, in January.
item.description: The Democratic Unionist Party of Northern Ireland strongly suggested that it would oppose Prime Minister Theresa May’s plan, damaging her hopes for its approval in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Suspect in Utrecht Tram Shooting Confessed, Prosecutors Say
item.media:description: Gokmen Tanis, 37, faces charges of terrorism for a shooting in Utrecht, the Netherlands, that killed three people.
item.media:credit: Utrecht Police, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The man, who faces terrorism charges in the Netherlands, made the admission in his first court hearing and told the judge that he had acted alone, according to Dutch prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Italy Gives Xi, and China’s Vast Infrastructure Project, a Royal Welcome
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, left, and President Sergio Mattarella of Italy at the Quirinale Palace in Rome on Friday.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Di Meo/ANSA, via Associated Press
item.description: Italy would become the first Group of 7 nation to officially join China’s vast One Belt One Road project on Saturday, a sign of Beijing’s growing influence.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: The Saturday Profile: 5 Popes, 150 Papal Trips and One Stern Lecture for Bishops
item.media:description: Valentina Alazraki, a journalist who covers the Vatican for the Mexican media company Televisa, made news herself recently with a stern lecture to Roman Catholic bishops about sexual abuse in the church.
item.media:credit: Agustín Salinas/El Uniuversal, via Associated Press
item.description: The Mexican journalist Valentina Alazraki made news herself recently when she warned Roman Catholic leaders to address clerical sexual abuse — or suffer the consequences.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: in her words: Jacinda Ardern Is Leading by Following No One
item.description: In the wake of a mass shooting, New Zealand’s prime minister has drawn international praise for mixing empathy with swift, concrete action.
item.dc:creator: MAYA SALAM

item.title: Where Does Brexit Go From Here?
item.media:description: Supporters and opponents of Brexit outside the Parliament in London. The process has left emotions running very high on both sides.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: After getting a short reprieve from the European Union, Parliament will try, again, to agree on a way forward, but the prospects remain uncertain.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: At War: The Art of War: ‘Promote World Peace...Kill Everyone!’
item.description: Readers share their photos of wartime graffiti from Iraq and Afghanistan and explain why it resonated with them.
item.dc:creator: LAUREN KATZENBERG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: March for a Second Brexit Vote Is Just the Start for Young People
item.media:description: Students and young people gathering in London in February at an event to support a second referendum on Britain’s membership in the European Union.
item.description: A mass demonstration planned for Saturday in London will be led by youthful activists who see it as the first step in a battle to reverse Brexit that could last decades.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: North Korea Pulls Staff From Liaison Office, Sending South a Message
item.description: The move was North Korea’s latest show of discontent since Kim Jong-un’s talks with President Trump in Hanoi, Vietnam, ended without a deal last month.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: International Herald Tribune: 1919: France Finds Thousands of Telegrams Not Sent During WWI
item.description: An investigation concluded that the country’s telegraphic service had been responsible for “scandalous abuses,” delaying as many as 40,000 messages per day.
item.dc:creator: THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Golan Heights, Brexit, N.C.A.A. Basketball: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Israeli forces near the Syrian border in the Golan Heights last year.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Istanbul Dispatch: In Istanbul, Erdogan Remakes Taksim Square, a Symbol of Secular Turkey
item.media:description: In Taksim Square in Istanbul, the skeleton of a large new mosque dwarfs the Ataturk monument, dedicated to the founder of Turkey’s secular republic.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: This popular urban patch has been a symbol of the secular republic for nearly 100 years, but six years after deadly protests there, contentious changes have begun to alter its character in major ways.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: At War: Afghan War Casualty Report: March 15-21
item.description: At least 45 pro-government forces and 12 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Video Dispatch: How Maduro Keeps Power in Venezuela, Even With the Lights Out
item.description: A weeklong outage deepened the country’s already crippling economic crisis. Our reporter crossed Caracas to see its impact on residents and how they view embattled President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: NEIL COLLIER and ORLANDO DE GUZMAN

item.title: Two U.S. Service Members Killed in Northern Afghanistan
item.description: One Afghan commando was also killed and two were wounded during a joint operation in a Taliban-held district in Kunduz Province, officials said.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Inside Venezuela’s Blackout, Maduro’s Power Endures
item.description: After years of economic crisis, many Venezuelans struggle just to get by. Yet President Nicolás Maduro continues to hold onto power, using state propaganda, repression and fear to contain the growing opposition.

item.title: Explosion at China Chemical Plant Kills 64; Employees Detained
item.media:description: Fires raged overnight at Jiangsu Tianjiayi Chemical Company, in the eastern Chinese province of Jiangsu, after an explosion on Thursday that killed at least 64 people.
item.description: An undisclosed number of factory personnel were held after the blast, which raised fears that toxic substances could spread.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Indonesia’s National Airline Seeks to Cancel Order of Boeing Max 8s
item.media:description: A Garuda Indonesia Boeing 737 Max 8 undergoing checks at Soekarno-Hatta International Airport near Jakarta, Indonesia.
item.description: The request from the carrier, Garuda Indonesia, is the first publicly confirmed attempt to cancel a Max 8 order since the deadly crash in Ethiopia this month.
item.dc:creator: MUKTITA SUHARTONO and AMIE TSANG
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
